Award.AwardTitle: The GUN201 Gene Family, a Novel Regulator of Chloroplast Biogenesis and Development
Award.AbstractNarration: A considerable amount of plant metabolism occurs within compartments of plant cells known as chloroplasts. This chloroplast-localized metabolism includes photosynthesis, the metabolism that converts solar energy into chemical energy and reduces carbon dioxide to carbohydrate. Photosynthesis underpins agriculture and indeed life on earth because this process drives the growth, development, and reproduction of plants. Chloroplast development and function is driven by many varied signals and interactions between distinct subcellular compartments of plants, but significant gaps remain in our knowledge of this process. This project will include the study of a small gene family that makes redundant contributions to processes that promote chloroplast development and function. The project will use an interdisciplinary approach that emphasizes genetics, cell biology, and biochemistry in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. The expected outcome is not only an understanding of the full contribution of this gene family to chloroplast development and function, but also the discovery of the particular biochemical reactions supported by this gene family. We expect that these findings will contribute significantly to the understanding of chloroplast development and function and to the integration of these processes with the development of entire plants. Because of the central role of the chloroplast to the growth, development, and reproduction of plants, these findings are expected to contribute solutions for significant agronomic issues such as tolerance to particular environmental stresses and the production of biofuels. In addition to providing these significant conceptual advances for plant biology, the proposed work will contribute to the career development of the next generation of plant biologists by providing laboratory training for graduate students and postdoctoral research associates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Photosynthesis supports every food chain on earth by converting solar energy into biologically useful forms of energy. Chloroplasts are the subcellular compartments that perform photosynthesis in plants and algae. Thus, the biogenesis and function of chloroplasts underpins life on our planet. We used a collection of mutants in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana that are deficient in different members of a small gene family that encodes proteins of unknown function to show that this gene family helps to establish the proportion of cellular volume devoted to chloroplasts. Indeed, we found that when each member of this gene family was deleted from this plant, the proportion of cellular volume devoted to chloroplasts was approximately 50% of normal plants. Other than the proteins encoded by this gene family, there are no candidates for proteins that contribute to a mechanism that establishes the proportion of cellular volume devoted to chloroplasts.

 

We provided insight into the mechanism that establishes the proportion of cellular volume devoted to chloroplasts by showing that the protein encoded by the member of this gene family that is most important for establishing the normal size of the chloroplast compartment resides in both the nucleus and the cytosol. Thus, a mechanism that resides outside of chloroplasts establishes the size of the chloroplast compartment. This finding is consistent with earlier work that provided evidence for a cellular compartment other than the chloroplast determining the size of the chloroplast compartment. We found that an herbicide that inhibits chloroplast function and cell expansion excludes this protein from the nucleus. Regulating the nucleocytoplasmic partitioning of proteins was previously demonstrated to regulate a number of important cellular processes. Based on these data, we conclude that signals derived from chloroplasts or cell expansion might regulate the mechanism that establishes the size of the chloroplast compartment. Consistent with this interpretation, the absolute size of the chloroplast compartment is tightly linked to the size of the cell and chloroplast function affects the cell expansion that underpins the expansion of the leaf lamina.

 

Although mechanisms that establish the proportion of cellular volume devoted to subcellular compartments are of fundamental importance to biology, these mechanisms remain poorly understood. In the particular case of chloroplasts, understanding these mechanisms will lead to significant advances for agriculture, such as increasing the efficiency of photosynthesis. Currently, inefficient photosynthesis appears to limit yields of important crops, such as rice. Thus, further study of this gene family will significantly increase our fundamental knowledge of biology and may lead to increased yields from important crops.
